title: Software
text:
Below is a list of software packages and tools I have developed:

rgexf: Build, Import and Export GEXF Graph Files (2020): R package version 0.16.0
ABCoptim: Implementation of Artificial Bee Colony (ABC) Optimization (2017): R package version 0.15.0
{{netdiffuseR: Analysis of Diffusion and Contagion Processes on Networks (2020): R package version 1.22.0
ergmito: Exponential Random Graph Models for Small Networks (2020): R package version 0.3-0
slurmR: A Lightweight Wrapper for ‘Slurm’ (2020): R package version 0.4-1
fmcmc: A friendly MCMC framework (2020): R package version 0.3-0
parallel: Stata Module for Parallel Computing (2019): Stata Module version 1.20.0
aphylo: Statistical Inference of Annotated Phylogenetic Trees (2022): R package version 0.2-1
netplot: Beautiful graph drawing (2021): R package version 0.1-1
barry: your to-go motif accountant (2020): C++ library version 0.0-1
pruner: Implementing the Felsenstein’s Tree Pruning algorithm (2020): C++ library version 0.0-1
{twitterreport: Out-of-the-box analysis and reporting tools for twitter: R package version 0.16
{epiworld (2022): C++ library version 0.0-1
defm: Estimation and simulation of Multi-binary response models (2023): R package version 0.1.0
epiworldR: Fast Agent-Based Epi Models (2023): R package version 0.0-2
epiworldRShiny: Shiny interface for epiworldR (2023): R package version 0.1-0
{PyRenew (2024): Python package version 0.1.0
wwinference: Jointly infers infection dynamics from wastewater data and epidemiological indicators (2024): R package version 0.1.1.99, https://cdcgov.github.io/ww-inference-model/

title: Software
text:
Development Philosophy
I believe in developing software that is:

Open Source: All my packages are freely available under permissive licenses
Well Documented: Comprehensive documentation with examples and tutorials

Tested: Rigorous testing to ensure reliability
Performant: Optimized for speed, especially for large-scale computations
User-Friendly: Intuitive APIs that follow R conventions

title: Software
text:
Contributions
I actively contribute to the R ecosystem and have contributed to various open-source projects. My packages are available on:

CRAN (The Comprehensive R Archive Network)
GitHub (Development versions and additional tools)

title: Software
text:
Support and Issues
If you encounter issues with any of my software or have feature requests, please:

Check the package documentation and examples
Search existing issues on the GitHub repository
Open a new issue with a reproducible example
For general questions, feel free to email me

title: Software
text:
Here are some of the key software packages I have developed:

netplot: Beautiful network plots using ggplot2
ergmito: ERGMs for small networks
slurmR: R and SLURM integration
ABCoptim: Artificial Bee Colony optimization
netdiffuseR: Network diffusion analysis
epiworldR: Agent-based modeling for epidemiology
rgexf: R package for GEXF graph files

For a complete and up-to-date list, please visit my GitHub profile or the software.bib file in my resume repository.
Note: This page will automatically fetch and display the latest software from my resume repository when the R packages are available in the build environment.

title: George G. Vega Yon
text:
I am an Assistant Professor of Research at the Division of Epidemiology at the University of Utah. I work on studying Complex Systems using Statistical Computing. I have over ten years of experience developing scientific software focusing on high-performance computing, data visualization, and social network analysis. My training is in Public Policy (M.A. UAI, 2011), Economics (M.Sc. Caltech, 2015), and Biostatistics (Ph.D. USC, 2020).
I obtained my Ph.D. in Biostatistics under the supervision of Prof. Paul Marjoram and Prof. Kayla de la Haye, with my dissertation titled “Essays on Bioinformatics and Social Network Analysis: Statistical and Computational Methods for Complex Systems.”
I’m available for coding, data science, network science, and data visualization consulting.

title: George G. Vega Yon
text:
I am an Assistant Professor of Research at the Division of Epidemiology at the University of Utah. I work on studying Complex Systems using Statistical Computing. I have over ten years of experience developing scientific software focusing on high-performance computing, data visualization, and social network analysis. My training is in Public Policy (M.A. UAI, 2011), Economics (M.Sc. Caltech, 2015), and Biostatistics (Ph.D. USC, 2020).
I obtained my Ph.D. in Biostatistics under the supervision of Prof. Paul Marjoram and Prof. Kayla de la Haye, with my dissertation titled “Essays on Bioinformatics and Social Network Analysis: Statistical and Computational Methods for Complex Systems.”
I’m available for coding, data science, network science, and data visualization consulting.

title: Talks
text:
This page automatically fetches the latest talks from my talks repository.


For the most up-to-date list of my talks and presentations, please visit:

GitHub Repository: gvegayon/talks
Direct Link: README.md




My talks typically cover topics in:

Statistical Computing: High-performance computing methods for statistical analysis
Network Analysis: Social network analysis methods and applications
Agent-Based Modeling: Epidemiological modeling using ABMs
R Package Development: Creating tools for the R ecosystem
Biostatistics: Statistical methods in health and biological research




If you’re interested in having me speak at your event, please feel free to contact me.
Note: This page will automatically fetch and display talks from my repository when the R packages are available in the build environment.

title: Publications
text:
For the most up-to-date list of my publications, please visit my Google Scholar profile.



Statistical Computing
Social Network Analysis
Biostatistics
High-Performance Computing
Data Visualization
Complex Systems




My research focuses on developing statistical methods and computational tools for analyzing complex systems, particularly in the areas of:

Network epidemiology: Developing models for disease spread in networks
Social network analysis: Creating tools for analyzing social structures
High-performance computing: Optimizing statistical algorithms for parallel computing
R package development: Contributing to the R ecosystem with specialized tools




Title: Essays on Bioinformatics and Social Network Analysis: Statistical and Computational Methods for Complex Systems
Institution: University of Southern California (USC)
Year: 2020
Advisors: Prof. Paul Marjoram and Prof. Kayla de la Haye

This page provides an overview of my research areas. For detailed publication lists, citation metrics, and full-text access, please visit my Google Scholar profile.

title: Publications
text:
Key Software Contributions
Many of my publications are accompanied by open-source software implementations. You can find these in the Software section or on my GitHub profile.

title: Publications
text:
Collaboration
I’m always interested in collaborative research opportunities. If you’re working on problems related to network analysis, statistical computing, or complex systems, feel free to reach out.

title: George G. Vega Yon - Quarto Website
text:
This is the source code for my personal website built with Quarto.



index.qmd - Homepage with bio and social links
talks.qmd - Automatically fetches talks from gvegayon/talks repository
publications.qmd - Links to Google Scholar profile and research overview
software.qmd - Automatically fetches software list from gvegayon/resume
_quarto.yml - Main configuration file
styles.css / custom.scss - Custom styling




The website is configured to automatically update weekly via GitHub Actions, fetching the latest: - Talks from the talks repository - Software from the resume repository
- Publications metadata



To build the website locally:

Install Quarto
Install required R packages: httr, rvest, stringr, rmarkdown, knitr
Run quarto render




The website is automatically built and deployed using GitHub Actions with the rocker/tidyverse:4.5.1 container, which includes Quarto and all necessary R packages.



The original HTML website is preserved in the public directory and serves as the baseline for the new Quarto version.
